prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require 0.17 km/s resolution in order to resolve the expected line width of order 0.5 km/s. Since the lines will be narrow, the bandwidth for C18O and 13CS are chosen to ensure sufficient line-free channels for good continuum subtraction. Larger bandwidths are chosen for 12CO and 13CO, which may show line-wing emission from outflows, and SiO which traces fast jet material.

The chosen angular resolution (1") allows us to fully resolve the pillars with enough beams that we can trace gradients in the turbulent line-width and internal motions. The largest angular scale is set by the size of the largest pillar structure, which is of order 3'.
The mosaic pointings were chosen by first selecting a rectangular mosaic with reference to the 70 micron Herschel images. However, due to the irregular nature of the cloud structures, using this alone would have resulted in wasted pointings. Therefore, we output the pointings from the OT, manually removed those which did not cover any emission, and then imported the remaining pointings back into the OT as a custom mosaic. The maps will therefore still be Nyquist sampled.

Our sensitivity is set by the need to detect the C18O J=2-1 line at at least 5 sigma in order to constrain its line-width. We estimate the line flux from the typical peak brightness temperature in C18O J=1-0 of 3K in the previously observed pillar in Vulpecula (Klaassen et al. 2014). Based on the observed dust temperature (18K) and density (8x10^3 cm^-3), RADEX finds that the observed C18O peak brightness temperature requires a C18O column density of 1.7x10^15 cm^-3, which in turn leads to a C18O J=2-1 peak brightness temperature of 4.1K. In a 1" beam, this corresponds to 160 mJy, so 5 sigma is 32 mJy/beam which we round down to 30 mJy/beam to be conservative. Indeed, the 70 and 160 micron continuum for all targeted pillars are brighter than that for the previously studied pillar, so this calculation is very conservative. 12CO and 13CO will be brighter than C18O.
We require a 0.17 km/s velocity resolution in all lines except SiO in order to resolve the typical line-width observed by Klaassen et al., of 0.5 km/s. For SiO, which is known to trace high-velocity jets, we smooth to 0.7 km/s to improve the s/n ratio for that line. 13CS will likely only be detected in dense cores.
The continuum flux density was calculated based on the lowest 70 and 160 micron Herschel fluxes of 1500 and 1000 MJy/sr respectively. Using s1/s2=(wav1/wav2)^alpha, we get alpha=0.49. We then convert the 70 micron flux to 1.3mm, resulting in 4191 My/sr which is 98 mJy/beam for a 1" beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ionised feedback from high-mass stars destroys molecular clouds, removing the reservoir for further star formation and restricting star formation efficiency to a few percent. Irradiated pillars are a key signpost of this process, with simulations suggesting that they are either (a) pre-existing filaments that have been revealed, or (b) formed via instabilities. Star formation may also be triggered during this process. Despite the importance of these processes to the global star formation cycle they are still poorly constrained, with only one pioneering study (Klaassen et al., 2014) testing the different pillar formation scenarios via high-resolution observations of the cold gas kinematics in the tip of one pillar in Vulpecula. Guided by our proof of concept study, we propose to observe 10 pillar regions with ALMA in the Carina star forming complex to systematically study the effects of feedback. The sample includes multiple pillars with a range of lengths irradiated by the same, well characterised ionising sources at a range of distances. These observations will, for the first time, reveal the global properties of the pillars and how they vary with radiation field and time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Proposal 2015.1.00493.S, 'The missing engine: a bipolar outflow without its star', PI A.F. Mc Leod is targeting the newly discovered outflow in one of the Pillars of Creation. Though our principle science goals are the different, observations for that project can be analysed and compared to the global properties obtained through our observations of Carina.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of
